title: Angular momentum conservation - sphere path radius

content.question: Two spheres are attached by lightweight strings to a small cylindrical container of negligible mass, as shown in the figures. Each sphere has mass <math alttext="m sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>, and the container-spheres-strings system is free to rotate about the center of the container. Initially, each sphere is a distance <math alttext="r sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>r</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> from the center as the system rotates with an angular speed <math alttext="omega sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>, and each sphere travels a distance <math alttext="d sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> in time <math alttext="delta t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>t</mi></math>. Next, a mechanism inside the box slowly releases some of the string until the spheres are each a distance <math alttext="2 r sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>r</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> from the center as the system continues to rotate. When the spheres are traveling in a circle of radius <math alttext="2 r sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>r</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>, what distance does each sphere travel in time <math alttext="delta t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>t</mi></math> ?
